text: It's important because at the end of the day, it is those business critical outcomes against which you and your team will be evaluated. That's the reality of working for a business, right? If you are contributing to the business in a way that the business at large can understand, that the CEO can understand, that the CFO can understand, if your team is a good investment for the business, then the business will continue making that investment.
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Lenny asks Matt why aligning work to business critical outcomes is so important. Matt explains that product managers and teams are increasingly being laid off, and CEOs are explicitly stating they have 'too many teams doing work around the work' rather than focusing on real impact. Matt emphasizes that teams will ultimately be evaluated based on their contribution to business critical outcomes, not on following best practices or shipping features.
text_ko: 중요한 이유는 결국 당신과 당신의 팀이 평가받는 기준이 바로 그런 비즈니스 핵심 성과(business critical outcomes)이기 때문이에요. 회사에서 일하는 현실이 그런 거잖아요. 조직 전체와 최고경영자(CEO), 최고재무책임자(CFO)까지 이해할 수 있는 방식으로 비즈니스에 기여하면, 당신의 팀이 회사에 투자할 만한 가치가 있다는 판단을 받을 거예요. 그러면 회사는 그 투자를 계속하게 될 거예요.
text_zh: 这个很重要，因为说到底，你和你的团队会根据这些关键业务成果来被评估。在公司工作就是这个现实，对吧？如果你对业务的贡献是整个公司都能理解的，CEO能理解的，CFO也能理解的，如果你的团队对公司来说是个好投资，那公司就会继续在你们身上投钱。
text_es: Es importante porque al final del día, van a evaluar a tu equipo y a ti en base a esos resultados críticos para el negocio. Esa es la realidad de trabajar en una empresa, ¿no? Si estás contribuyendo al negocio de una manera que toda la empresa pueda entender, que el CEO pueda entender, que el CFO pueda entender, si tu equipo es una buena inversión para el negocio, entonces la empresa va a seguir haciendo esa inversión.

text: The message that Daniel Ek from Spotify sent out with their layoffs in 2024 said, 'We still have too many teams doing work around the work and supporting work, rather than focusing on opportunities with real impact.' And that really struck a nerve because I've been on those supporting teams before. I've done the work around the work.
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Lenny asks what this focus on business impact is a reaction to, wondering why many product teams aren't already driving business impact. Matt explains that more product managers and teams are being laid off, citing a specific example from Spotify's CEO Daniel Ek who explicitly stated the problem: too many teams doing 'work around the work' instead of focusing on real impact.
text_ko: 다니엘 에크(Daniel Ek)가 2024년 해고와 관련해 보낸 메시지에서 '우리는 여전히 실제로 영향력 있는 기회에 집중하기보다는 일을 지원하는 팀이 너무 많다'고 했어요. 이 말이 정말 와닿았어요. 저도 예전에 그런 지원 팀에서 일해본 적이 있거든요. 일을 둘러싼 일을 한 경험이 있어요.
text_zh: Spotify的Daniel Ek在2024年裁员时发的那个消息说，"我们还是有太多团队在做一些围绕工作的工作，做一些支持性的工作，而不是专注于那些真正有影响力的机会。" 这话真的戳中了我的痛点，因为我以前就在那种支持团队里待过，我也做过那种为了工作而工作的事情。
text_es: El mensaje que mandó Daniel Ek de Spotify cuando hicieron los recortes en 2024 decía: "Todavía tenemos demasiados equipos haciendo trabajo alrededor del trabajo y apoyando el trabajo, en lugar de enfocarse en oportunidades con impacto real." Y eso realmente me tocó la fibra porque yo he estado en esos equipos de apoyo antes. He hecho ese trabajo alrededor del trabajo.

text: So the first question I ask most of the teams I work with is if you were the CEO of this company, would you fully fund your own team? And frankly, most of the people I ask that question to don't know the answer right away. They're not sure. They say, 'I think so,' or, 'Yeah, yeah. Yeah, because...' And then you can see the gears turning.
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Lenny asks for ways product managers can stress test whether they're actually driving impact or just think they are. Matt shares his go-to question for teams he works with: asking them to think like a CEO and consider whether they would fully fund their own team. He notes that most people can't answer this confidently, which indicates they may not understand their team's true value to the business.
text_ko: 제가 함께 일하는 팀들한테 가장 먼저 묻는 질문이 있어요. "만약 당신이 이 회사의 CEO라면, 자신의 팀에 전적으로 자금을 대겠어요?" 솔직히 말하면 그 질문을 받는 사람들 대부분은 바로 답을 못해요. 확신이 없죠. "그럴 것 같아요" 또는 "네, 네. 왜냐하면…" 하고 말하면서 머릿속에서 생각이 돌아가는 게 보여요.
text_zh: 所以我和团队合作时，第一个问题通常是：如果你是这家公司的CEO，你会全力支持自己的团队吗？说实话，大部分人听到这个问题都答不上来，不太确定。他们会说"应该会吧"，或者"嗯嗯，会的，因为..."然后你就能看出他们在那儿琢磨。
text_es: Entonces la primera pregunta que les hago a la mayoría de los equipos con los que trabajo es: si ustedes fueran el CEO de esta empresa, ¿financiarían completamente a su propio equipo? Y la verdad, la mayoría de las personas a las que les hago esa pregunta no saben la respuesta de inmediato. No están seguros. Dicen "Creo que sí" o "Sí, sí. Sí, porque..." Y ahí puedes ver cómo se les mueven los engranajes.

text: The Low Impact Death Spiral is the dynamic in which every medium to large company I've ever worked with finds itself in one way or another. It starts with teams taking on low impact work. Adding little features here and there, making little cosmetic improvements because it's easier, it invites less scrutiny and you're less likely to mess up something important.
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Lenny asks Matt to explain the 'Low Impact PM Death Spiral' concept from his book. Matt describes this as a common dynamic where product teams gravitate toward low-risk, low-impact work like small features and cosmetic improvements because it's safer and invites less scrutiny. This creates a cycle where low-impact work makes it harder to do high-impact work, leading teams deeper into irrelevant projects until layoffs occur.
text_ko: 영향이 적은 데스 스파이럴(Low Impact Death Spiral)은 제가 일해본 거의 모든 중대형 회사들이 어떤 식으로든 빠져 있는 역학이에요. 보통 팀들이 영향이 적은 업무(low-impact work)를 맡는 것부터 시작돼요. 여기저기 작은 기능을 붙이거나, 보기 좋게 하는 정도의 사소한 개선만 하는 식인데, 그게 더 쉽고 검토도 덜 들어오니까 중요한 걸 망칠 위험이 적거든요.
text_zh: 低影响死亡螺旋(Low Impact Death Spiral)这个现象，我合作过的中大型公司基本都会碰到。一开始呢，团队就爱接一些没什么影响力的活儿。这里加个小功能，那里改改界面什么的，做些表面功夫，因为这样省事儿嘛，不容易被人挑毛病，也不太可能把重要的东西搞砸。
text_es: La Espiral de la Muerte de Bajo Impacto es esa dinámica en la que se meten todas las empresas medianas y grandes con las que he trabajado, de una forma u otra. Empieza cuando los equipos se enfocan en trabajo de poco impacto. Van agregando funcionalidades menores por aquí y por allá, haciendo mejoritas cosméticas porque es más fácil, genera menos ruido con los jefes y hay menos chance de que la riegues con algo importante.

text: You can follow all the best practices and have the highest velocity and do everything quote-unquote 'right', but if your company goes out of business, they're not going to say, 'Yeah, we're going out of business, but we're going to keep writing your paycheck for two years because all of your OKRs were a 0.6 or a 0.7.'
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Matt discusses the emotional challenge of being accountable for things outside our control, like business impact that depends on market conditions and customer behavior. He explains that while we naturally want to avoid accountability for uncontrollable factors, the reality is that business success affects us regardless. He uses this example to illustrate that following best practices doesn't protect you if the business fails.
text_ko: 모든 최선의 방법을 따르고, 속도도 최고로 유지하고, 모든 걸 '제대로' 해도, 만약 회사가 망하게 된다면, '그래, 우리는 망하지만, 너의 OKR이 0.6이나 0.7이었으니까 2년 동안 너의 월급은 계속 줄게'라고 하진 않을 거예요.
text_zh: 你可以遵循所有最佳实践，保持最高的执行速度，把所谓的"正确"事情都做到位，但如果公司倒闭了，他们不会说："是的，我们要关门了，不过因为你所有的OKRs都达到了0.6或0.7的完成度，所以我们还会继续给你发两年工资。"
text_es: Puedes seguir todas las mejores prácticas y tener la velocidad más alta y hacer todo "como debe ser", pero si tu empresa quiebra, no te van a decir: "Sí, nos vamos a la quiebra, pero te vamos a seguir pagando el sueldo dos años más porque todos tus OKRs estuvieron en 0.6 o 0.7."

text: So the first step, and I think the most important and where a lot of my work plays out is in setting team goals, close to company goals. No more than one step away from company goals. Don't let it get cascaded into oblivion.
speaker: Matt LeMay
context: Lenny asks about Matt's three steps to become more of an impact-first product team. Matt explains the first and most critical step: setting team goals that are no more than one step away from company goals. He references Christina Wodtke's concept from 'Radical Focus' about avoiding multi-level goal cascading that leads to team goals that can't be traced back to company objectives.
text_ko: 그래서 첫 번째 단계이자 제가 가장 중요하다고 생각하는 건 팀 목표를 회사 목표에 최대한 가깝게, 즉 회사 목표에서 한 단계 이내로 설정하는 거예요. 목표가 하향식으로 전파(cascade)되면서 흐지부지해지지 않도록 하세요.
text_zh: 所以第一步，也是我觉得最关键的一步，也是我大部分工作重点，就是设定团队目标，要跟公司目标紧密挂钩。最多只能偏离公司目标一步，千万别让目标在层层传递中变得面目全非。
text_es: Entonces el primer paso, y creo que es el más importante y donde se concentra gran parte de mi trabajo, es definir objetivos de equipo que estén muy alineados con los objetivos de la empresa. Como máximo un escalón por debajo de los objetivos corporativos. No dejes que se diluyan pasando de nivel en nivel hasta que no signifiquen nada.
